#summary Available conditions
=Conditions=

Following class and object definitions are referred in the examples
{{{
class Dto
{
    private int id;
    private String text;

    public int getId()
    {
        return id;
    }

    public int getText()
    {
        return text;
    }
}

Collection<Dto> testList = new ArrayList<>();
testList.Add(new Dto());
}}}

==Equality==
In following code list would be filtered so that only item with id = 1 is returned
{{{
Filter<Dto> query = CQ.<Dto>filter()
        .from(testList)
        .where()
        .property(Dto::getId).eq().value(1);
Collection<Dto> filtered = query.list();
}}}

==Less Than==
In following code list would be filtered so that only items with id < 2 are returned
{{{
Filter<Dto> query = CQ.<Dto>filter()
        .from(testList)
        .where()
        .property(Dto::getId).lt().value(2);

Collection<Dto> filtered = query.list();
}}}

==Less than or equal==
Similar to the Less than condition but function le() should be used instead of lt()

==Greater than==
Similar to the Less than condition but function gt() should be used instead of lt()

==Greater than or equal==
Similar to the Less than condition but function ge() should be used instead of lt()

==In==
{{{
In following code list would be filtered so that only items with id 1 or 2 are returned
Filter<Dto> query = CQ.<Dto>filter()
        .from(testList)
        .where()
        .property(Dto::getId).in().value(new int[]{1,2});

Collection<Dto> filtered = query.list();
}}}

It can be re-parsed to use a collection instead of an array.
{{{
Filter<Dto> query = CQ.<Dto>filter()
        .from(testList)
        .where()
        .property(Dto::getId).in().value(Arrays.asList(1,2));

Collection<Dto> filtered = query.list();
}}}

==Between==
In following code list would be filtered so that only items with id greater than or equal to 1 and less than or equal to 2 are returned
{{{
Filter<Dto> query = CQ.<Dto>filter()
        .from(testList)
        .where()
        .property(Dto::getId).between().value(1).value(2);

Collection<Dto> filtered = query.list();
}}}

==And==
In following code list would use and to join two conditions. Items with id greter than 1 and less than 3 are returned
{{{
Filter<Dto> query = CQ.<Dto>filter()
        .from(testList)
        .where()
        .property(Dto::getId).gt().value(1)
        .and()
        .property(Dto::getId).lt().value(3);

Collection<Dto> filtered = query.list();
}}}

When using and set of the conditions before {{{and()}}} would be associated with the left hand side of the and condition.
ex: {{{(x == 1).and().(y == 2).and().(x < 10).and().(y > 1)}}} would be interpreted as, {{{(((x == 1) && (y == 2)) && (x < 10)) && (y > 1)}}}

==Or==
Similar to the and condition.
